This time I am on dose dense A/C and then I will start Taxol/herceptin weekly.  In my case, the dose dense A/C is much better tolerated than the TCH.  A little more nausea, but other than this, I am doing much better than the other regimen.

Posts.Title: Surgery or No Surgery....this is the question my2boys my2boys

Posts.Content: my2boys wrote: My left breast has developed capsular contracture due to the radiation treatments I had last year.  My plastic surgeon has told me that he could do a surgery where he goes in and removes as much scar tissue as possible, replacing my implant with a new one and this should free up the hard capsule.  He also said he wants to remove two very large bands of scar tissue in my left armpit.  I am in moderate discomfort now with the hard implant and I am hopeful to find some relief with the surgery.  My oncologist has told me that this surgery is pretty common post-radiation. My question is about the lymphedema in my left arm.  I am worried that surgery will make it worse.  I use compression daily and a night sleeve each night and for the most part it hasn't gotten too much worse until recently.  I was at a wedding last fall and danced a little too much with no sleeve on while enjoying a glass or two of wine and BINGO...lymphedema flared up and hasn't let up since.  The plastic surgeon said his surgery shouldn't make the lymphedema worse OR better, but he said the decision is mine whether to go ahead with it. Any suggestions? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery or No Surgery....this is the question my2boys my2boys

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 11:12AM my2boys wrote: I spent the morning with my LE Therapist.  She said that the removal of the scar tissue is a good thing and although it is my decision, I shouldn't let fear of worsening lymphedema keep me from having the surgery.  She said that once the scar tissue is removed, I may even see a little improvement in the lymphedema because the scar tissue may be what is preventing some of the fluid from moving like it did before radiation treatments.  I have decided to go ahead with it.  It won't be for a few months yet, but I will keep you posted. There is a certain amount of peace once a plan is in place and a decision is made.  Praying for a good outcome.
Posts.Title: Surgery or No Surgery....this is the question my2boys my2boys

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 12:38PM my2boys wrote: I did Taxol.  My doctor had me do 12 weekly treatments instead of one larger dose every three weeks.  She said they would be easier to tolerate.  I have to say she was right about the Taxol.  Much easier than the A/C and I vacationed, ate and drank like normal.  I really felt great!  Cell counts were good and didn't need neulasta.  My hair started to grow back while on Taxol too....very slowly, but started growing. :o)
Posts.Title: Any words of wisdom for Taxol? lanagraves shlichte

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 01:12PM my2boys wrote: revricki - I used Nioxin #2 Cleansing Shampoo, Scalp Conditioner and Scalp Treatment.  To start, you should be able to find a box with all three.When I began using the Herbatint on my hair I switched to #3 because #3 is for color treated hair.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2009 01:07PM - edited Jun 14, 2009 09:46PM by my2boys Lisa - It seems like us TCH girls are a bit slower with regrowth.  Believe me, my hair is not growing like a weed by any stretch of the imagination.  It is about an inch long on the sides, back and rear/top.  The very front by my forehead is only about 1/2 inch long because this was the last part to come in.  When I say "trim" I mean she trimmed around my ears to clean it up and used the buzz cut thing to even out the sides.  Then she uses the scissors to clip the straggly pieces on top.  It is still thin on top and I am hoping that it will fill in eventually.  I found that once the hairdresser was done, it actually seemed normal, but VERY short.  You and I are on the same schedule, so my guess is that you are thin and short.  I think that the Herceptin is slowing us down.  Hang in there, Okay? Chelev - I agree about the short hairstyle thing.  I always had hair that was a little longer than shoulder length.  When I think that this time last year I was stressing about whether or not to grow my bangs out.....oh boy did I get more than I bargained for.  Two months is still early, so I guess you will have to sit back and wait a bit.  I didn't realize how much my hair was progressing until I saw a picture of myself from April (2 months out) and I was all scalp back then.  I am hoping that my top will thicken up to the point where you cannot see any scalp, but for now I am just happy to be the lady with the short, short hair. Good luck. Anne
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 30, 2010 08:59AM my2boys wrote: My surgeon told me that port removal is an in-office procedure with local anesthesia.  Putting it in was a bigger deal. I finished my year of Herceptin last October and I scheduled the port removal soon afterward.  Then one of the nurses at MSKCC advised me to hold onto it for a year, so I canceled my appointment.  I went back every six weeks to have it flushed.  I'm glad I held onto the port, because the cancer returned just a few months later and I'm back in treatment.  I'm used to the port and happy that I chose not to have it removed. At this point, it was one less thing for me to worry about.
Posts.Title: How long before you had your port removed? Charley KDob3

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 09:07AM - edited Jun 13, 2009 09:08AM by my2boys Hi Ladies, I just thought I would share my experience with you.  My last chemo was on February 11th (TCH) and I am currently on Herceptin every three weeks.  My hair is fully grown in on the sides and back and the top is finally filled in, but it took a long time.  You can still see my scalp  a tiny bit, but it's not bald all all.  It is around 1 inch long, but once the hairdresser shaved my neck and evened out the sides, it looks a bit like Jamie Lee Curtis on those yogurt commercials.  I have had two trims at the salon.  My chemo was Taxotere/Carboplatin and so I never really lost all of my hair, but it was almost all out.   My hairdresser used Herbatint on my hair and the hair took very nicely to it.  I would recommend this product if you are trying to stay away from chemical hair color treatments.  She also used the Herbatint on my eyebrows....they are still very thin.  This helped a lot!  I have been using Nioxin cleanser and scalp treatment for about 1-1/2 weeks and I started by using the Step 1 treatments for thin to normal hair.  Since now my hair is colored (Herbatint) I have switched to Nioxin Step 3 which is for colored hair.  Step 3 does not affect the color.  It still looks fine.  I will pop in again and let you know how I progress.  I am hoping to see some progress in thickening up my top. I hope that my experience will help some of you.  Good luck. Anne
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Title: What's your wierdest side effect ann-idiot ann-idiot

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2013 08:06PM - edited Sep 15, 2013 08:08PM by my2boys Just adding my two cents here. I have been going for acupuncture for my lymphedema for one year and it has improved somewhat. My acupuncturist is using the Sloan study and replicating most of the points except for the one point directly on the LE arm. He does, however, do the points on the shoulder of the LE arm. My swelling has improved slightly and he also seems to be helping with the scar tissue. I noticed an increase in symptoms over the summer when I didn't visit my acupuncturist as much (maybe only 2 or 3 times) and ever since I started up going regularly again, I am showing improvement again. Acupuncture isn't for everyone, but it really helps! The key is finding a good acupuncturist. I have always worn garments and done manual massages every day and I have continued with those as well, so I use acupuncture in addition to regular care, not instead of regular care. One additional note....my knee was bothering me for months and acupuncture helped tremendously with this. Apparently, it reduces swelling. My stress level is greatly improved too!
Posts.Title: LE and accupuncture: the Sloan Kettering study appears flawed kira purple32

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 05:58PM - edited Nov 15, 2008 06:02PM by my2boys Hi Laura, I chose the bilateral mastectomy instead of the lumpectomy because I am difficult to screen.  My mammo, sonograms and MRI all had benign findings, but I could feel my lump as plain as day.  I was worried that I would be impossible to screen if I kept my breasts.  I decided that my breasts weren't that important to me so I opted say goodbye to them.  It turns out that once they were removed, they found another tumor that was bigger than the original one they removed and they also found abnormal cells in my "healthy" breast.  This reinforced my decision and I was happy that I decided to go the route I did.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 12:25PM my2boys wrote: Dear Stacey, Just like Lisa said, what you are feeling is completely normal.  I remember last October before I started my treatments, I had terrible visions of what was to come.  After making it through the first one just fine, what a relief!  I can assure you that what you are fearing is the unknown.  Please understand that once you go through the actual treatment, the ones that follow will not be nearly as much of a concern for you. I hope that your side effects are minimal and you breeze through just fine.  By the way, the port was a great idea.  My port has worked out just fine. Keep the faith. Anne
Posts.Title: Nervous about starting Chemo 1/2/09 AZStacey2008 AZStacey2008

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 07:32PM my2boys wrote: You're welcome Stacey.  If I might add one more suggestion.....ask the people at the treatment center to give you something to calm your nerves before the first treatment.  I'm glad that your husband will be with you.  My husband and I make it a practice to bring along a board game or a deck of cards to help the time pass by.....of course he always lets me win....lol.  I also bring along pictures of my children and put them on the table next to the infusion chair. I promise you that the day will just fly by.  I had my 4th Tx yesterday and I'm fine today, really.  Just a bit tired.  Keep smiling and you will be O.K. Anne
Posts.Title: Nervous about starting Chemo 1/2/09 AZStacey2008 AZStacey2008

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2012 12:22PM - edited Jan 25, 2012 12:24PM by my2boys It hasn't been 5 years for me, but I was diagnosed in 2008 and went through 6 treatments of TCH only to have recurrence in early 2010.  I was immediately put on A/C TH.  4 A/C and then 12 weekly Taxol with Herceptin every third week.  I was also on Tykerb with the Herceptin.  I have to say that I found the A/C TH much easier to tolerate than the TCH.  I had much more energy and exercised my way right through it.  I didn't experience the fatigue and shortness of breath that I felt with TCH.  Other than a little nausea and a lot of dry mouth, nothing to complain about.  My heart is checked every three months and the cardiologist says it looks just fine.  I'm on Herceptin and Arimidex now and I feel great! I never thought of the chemo as poison, just strong medicine.  If I had never had it, I might not be here today.
